awd_titl_txt: Dual Polarization Radar Observations, Analysis and Retrievals of Convective Lifecycle during RELAMPAGO
awd_abstract_narration:
Traditionally meteorological radars have observed storms using single polarization to measure the intensity and velocity within storms.  Past research has shown that significantly more information about the storms, their particle types, and stage of evolution can be gleamed from using two orthogonal polarizations in radars.   This research focuses on the dual-polarization radar observations during the RELAMPAGO experiment in west Central Argentina. This region has among the most intense convective systems in the world in terms of frequency of large hail, very high storm tops, and extreme lightning activity, yet much remains unknown about the intense convection in this region. Because of the repeatability of storms in the region, this experiment will observe these storms to address science questions related to the initiation, initial organization/severe-weather generation, and growth stages of storm development, which are poorly understood.  This research will improve the understanding of, and the ability to predict, severe convective storms worldwide. Similar environments exist in many parts of the world including the US Rocky Mountains and Asia (such as Chengdu basin in China and Himalayan plains on the Indian subcontinent). The radar techniques developed from this project has the potential to benefit all the nationwide deployment of dual-polarization radars in the US.

This project will specifically address the analysis and retrieval of dual-polarization radar observations in some of the most intense convective storms, developing advanced retrieval techniques. The RELAMPAGO field observation set up will elucidate the tight connections between the, complex terrain, and the production of severe weather, role of terrain in initiating and developing organized convective storms and resultant intensity.  Development and application of advanced radar techniques, specially using frequency domain procedures, to identify the type of precipitation particles in the storm is an important part of this project.

por.por_cntn:
The CSU C-band Hydrological Instrument for Volumetric Observations (CSU-CHIVO) radar was deployed in Argentina to study the tallest storms on earth. This region in Argentina is known for having some of the most severe storms on the planet. CSU-CHIVO was disassembled packed and shipped to Argentina from the Colorado State University Radar Facility. In Argentina, CSU-CHIVO collected dual polarization radar observations over many severe storms. This valuable data is being looked at and will be analyzed to understand the physical processes behind severe storms.

 

Our team has studied the data from CSU-CHIVO and used the network of radars deployed during the campaign to obtain advanced network-radar retrievals. These retrievals have provided important insights into the microphysics of storms. We have also used this radar network to cross validate satellite borne radar observations in this region.  Historically our own team and other researchers in the community have studied cross validation between ground based and space borne radar observations of storms to get a perspective on calibration. In this research we have conducted simultaneous calibration of the ground radar and space radar network which is a first.   CSU CHIVO based analysis was used to study storm top statistics as observed by the radar. Initial finding shows that it is not uncommon to find 18 to 20 km tall storms, and it was an important goal of the experiment to observe these tall storms.

 

The radar data collected during RELAMPAGO provides an extremely valuable data set to enhance our understanding of continental convection, its internal processes, and its impacts on society in a geographically unique region defined by its significant and complex topography. The observations reveal the unique character of storm systems across the convective spectrum in Argentina that produce high-impact weather including hail, flash flooding, and high lightning flash rates in a global convective hotspot. The unique storm environment, the role of orographic flows, and storm-internal processes in producing tall, wide convective updrafts, hail-producing but non-tornadic severe convective storms, high lightning flash rates, and rapid convective mode transitions and upscale growth were documented with detailed and comprehensive observations, allowing connections between storm environment, kinematics, and microphysical processes in intense convection to be revealed. We expect this data set to continue to be used by researchers for the foreseeable future.
